por.por_cntn:
The NSF Grant “Collaborative Research: Expanded Correlative Dynamics and Meteor Studies Using the Southern Argentina Agile MEteor Radar (SAAMER)” employed SAAMER radar and correlative instrument observations performed from Rio Grande, Argentina and related modeling from 1 September 2017 to 28 February 2022. These efforts included a no-cost extension to enable completion of a range of research papers including the following:

1)    various measurement analyses addressing larger-scale dynamics of, and interactions among, atmospheric tides, planetary waves, and mean flows that account for the larger-scale circulation and structure of the atmosphere at altitudes of ~70-108 km;

2)    additional analyses addressing smaller-scale gravity wave (GW) and shear-flow instabilities leading to turbulence and mixing: and

3)    related modeling of GW and turbulence dynamics extending from the surface to very high altitudes that also generate secondary GWs and acoustic waves that can play significant roles in atmospheric circulation and structure extending to higher altitudes.  

All of these dynamics extending from very small turbulence to planetary scales are coupled in intricate ways and collectively account for our weather, the dynamics driving Earth’s climate, and their variability on time-scales from hours to decades.   

Two studies of large-scale dynamics included exploration of the quasi-2-day wave (Q2DW) structure and variability that have major impacts on the wind and temperature fields extending from ~30 km in the stratosphere into the thermosphere above ~100 km. These studies employed radar observations over a wide range of latitudes and satellite instrument measurements of temperatures enabling inferred winds and a decomposition of the fields into the major Q2DW components comprising the overall Q2DW field having differing periods ranging from ~42-54 hr. These studies provided key insights into the interplay among the various Q2DW components and the global tides excited by deep convection and ozone UV absorption in the troposphere and stratosphere, respectively.

Additional studies by NASA and other colleagues elsewhere employed SAAMER and other S. Hemisphere radar data to also evaluate the spatial and temporal variability of the tidal modes having fractions of the solar diurnal tide 24-hr period (e.g., at periods of 12, 8, and 6 hr).

MW activity excited by the high terrain to the west and NW of Rio Grande was a focus of four high-resolution modeling studies addressing their instability dynamics due to MW “breaking” and the secondary GWs and acoustic waves that arise from these smaller-scale dynamics. The foci of the first two of these were on the MW, secondary GW, and acoustic wave dynamics from lower altitudes into the mesosphere and lower thermosphere at altitudes of ~80-180 km. The later two papers addressed a critical need in global modeling of these dynamics, specifically the question of what spatial resolution is required for models intended to provide quantitative descriptions of these dynamics enabling their relatively quantitative descriptions if weather and climate prediction models. The results of these latter studies revealed that even the best global models are still unable to achieve sufficiently accurate descriptions of these responses, hence will require guidance in the development of representations of these dynamics by models that can adequately quantify these dynamics.  

Finally, provision of global radar data (29 radars) by the GATS SAAMER team for assimilation by the NAVy Global Environment Model (NAVGEM) yielding reanalysis data similar to the NASA MERRA2 dataset extending only to 60 km, but extending to higher altitudes of ~140 km with NAVGEM, as a reference atmosphere supporting local observations and analyses anywhere on Earth.
